comments.commentBody:
Now that Attorney General will have little involvement in any investigation should a nonpartisan independent investigation be convened into the extent of Russian manipulation and collusion with any members of the Trump campaign team, Jeff Sessions will have an opportunity to focus on other matters such as the reluctance of sanctuary cities to comply with federal immigration laws and policies.

While the Congressional subcommittee continues their own investigation into the Russian matter and other member of Congress step up their side show as a means to differ and stall appointments if government agencies, did it ever occur to them if these agencies function in the interim with little impact on their functions plays into President Trump's request for a more streamlined government?

If you strip away all these allegations and disregard all of the Obama leaks, what are you left with? The truth, which is that President Obama allowed the Russians to hack an election (his claim) and did nothing about it, and a DNC that was in cahoots with one of the candidates.

Democrats are obviously working very hard to obstruct this from remaining the one true story of the election.
Yes and the tweeter in-chief isn't even bright enough to figure out the pic was years old

It's only Global 'back room' politics where Putin and Trump are dividing up the worlds money and resources. Two thieves in backroom conspiracy and all the U.S. supporting characters completely unfit for such a conspiracy. These members of the "lunatic fringe" are Traitors to the American Sovereignty, traitors to the truth, traitors to morality, justice, equality before the law, and all for power, money, and fame. Small people playing spies. They may end up at the end of a rope. Deservedly.
It is a total witch hunt - he's a witch destroying our society and soul, and he deserves to be exorcised and thrown in jail. Lock him up, I say (now where did I get that phrase from?).
Apparently the Pope doesn't need to deal with alcoholic, drug-addicted aggressive panhandlers on a daily basis.

Apparently the Pope thinks that alcoholic, drug-addicted aggressive panhandlers are people.
Is he mistaken?
You need to learn more about the Pope.  He has spent much of his life in service to the poor.
They are people who the market has devalued. See: Prosperity Gospel for full details.
Harder they come, harder they fall.

This is a problem that requires an immense understanding of technology, geopolitics, culture, the individual psychology of North Korean leaders, military strategy, and diplomacy.

And we have a game-show host as president.
No. We have replaced a community organizer with a successful billionaire businessman.

You forget he surrounded himself with people who will guide him through the next day. The few who know anything will get lost in the shuffle.

As so called president Trump asked the military and intelligence community representatives when being briefed to assume the role of President and a world leader, "So why can't America just drop the bomb?"

So why can't America just drop the bomb?

America can just drop the bomb and then Jesus will float down to earth as the chosen people Jews will ascend and the 1,000 year rule of God will begin and then the kids can during intermission go to the refrigerator to get some snacks.

Oops! Someone blew away the refrigerator, the front lawn, the neighborhood, the country, the world.

Sorry kids, maybe we can have snacks next time.

Once upon a time we had a children's party clown as President. While I thought the entire eight-year episode was a national embarrassment, there are still plenty of Americans who swear by RR, or take an oath on his Bible.
People who believe that nature has a personality are usually bad at discerning fact from fiction. Whatever the US is, it is not "under God".
7, 11, 15 this week

Not that good old boy 'standing' bit from Wisconsin again. As if standing on rigid extremist principles is anything to rally around. This standing bit might be acceptable if Wisconsin Republicans could simultaneously stand, discuss issues, and govern with fairness.

Voters vote against their own interests when Scott Walker bids. They have a right to vote against their own interests. They need not then wonder, why has the government taken away our rights? For pure ideology, voters gave power to the government because Scott Walker said they ought. Voters voted against their own interest and hamstrung everybody else. Scott Walker, leaning to fascism, takes direct advantage of voters who think the only goal of government is lowering taxes and transferring citizens’ power to the government. Some wonder why the government takes away their health insurance. Some wonder why the government herds them like sheep. Trump’s answer is the same as Scott Walker’s answer: the government has no interest in health insurance. Get your own. Keep out of government’s way. The government is not a citizen-interest. The government is for itself which is fascism. Americans hate socialism and ignore that the name of Hitler’s political party recognized that fascism is ultimate socialism. Scott Walker’s column is self-congratulation, so familiar in 2017, for success in taking power from indifferent people of Wisconsin.
When citizens will it, government takes over their lives. That is the government’s chess game. Scott Walker and Donald J. Trump approve, play well and benefit bigly.

People, do not elect a governor such as ours in Wisconsin. He is not a “conservative” in the truest sense of the word (one who supports traditional institutions; marked by moderation or caution—Merriam Webster). He is a radical. He is a bomb-thrower. His purpose is only to serve a small minority of people who have little to no compassion for poor people, those afflicted with mental or physical disabilities, those who are somehow different from his view of the norm, which appears to be white and obeisant to the upper classes (tax cuts to the rich). Like our President, he does not bother to learn from former leaders who truly were conservative, such as Warren Knowles, Lee Sherman Dreyfuss or Tommy Thompson. He is a “divider and conqueror” (his exact words). His idea of “standing strong” against protestors is to run away. In Wisconsin, he used a series of tunnels to avoid citizens. He believes that his draconian views need to be protected at all costs, whether he conducts state business behind closed doors (how he ordered legislative leaders to hold hearings on Act 10 in Wisconsin), or more to his liking, ignore and redefine crucial research and evidence that his proposals will hurt large segments of the state. He will simply rephrase the argument to suit his needs, and good-hearted Wisconsinites will believe him. But someday, he will have to answer for his deceitful policies that have hurt Wisconsinites in real ways, and it’s not just those angry protestors in the cities.

Overreach seems to be common to any politician in the thrall of power, not just a trait of a villainous Federal government. In South Dakota, a state dominated by Republicans who cringe at Federal interference, state-level overreach is often  more repugnant than anything the feds might do, precisely because it is perpetrated in such a close and personal way. From rewriting an initiated bill raising the minimum wage, to using an emergency clause to permanently kill an initiated bill on government corruption, our legislature displays an in-your-face contempt for the voter. Where state acquisition of Federal land is concerned, our Governor blithely ignores public furor at his plan to acquire Forest Service land for a misbegotten state park that will only accelerate a trend of environmental destruction from the over-marketing of adjacent state-held lands. There is no magical enlightenment that enters the politician's soul through geographic proximity, Governor Walker. That is just another right-wing fairytale manufactured to mask your bondage to the interests of the wealthy few. Beneath this sham enlightenment, you cook-up as many ways as possible for the poorest citizens to carry the greatest share of the tax burden and for your friends in business to evade the  full cost of labor. As our state-level Republican brothers and sisters overreach with one hand to push us down, they reach around us with the the other to deprive us of our wallets. A huckster's sleight of hand.

SK: I live in a farming area and know lots of farmers. This isn't a good argument. Yes, the urban areas need farm products, but they can get them (and do) from other countries. Most of those cities are ports, remember? Inland farmers in the U.S. need to be able to sell their products to the cities and use their ports in order to export. So if cities kept their own taxes and managed their own affairs, rural farmers would not be "free" to withhold their products from those markets without destroying their own livelihoods.

What I have seen in the State of Indiana is legislators bought and paid for by Big Business-controlled ALEC. It is not states' rights; it is favoritism toward wealthy campaign contributors and those who wine and dine legislators. Scott Walker himself is bought and paid for by the billionaire Koch brothers.

What I have also seen is that those state legislators who cry "States' Rights" turn around and take away freedom from local governments to act in the best interest of their citizens, and from individual citizens. Indiana is one of the states in which a criminalization of protest bill was introduced. The issue is not state versus federal, it is that too many people in government want only power and money for themselves. They are not public servants. The Republicans in Congress are busily enacting new regulations. It is just that their preferred regulations are different from Democrats' preferred regulations.

I am confounded by any elected official who blasts the federal government, as if one branch of government is the enemy and one is good. How childish. Without the federal government, Mississippi would have segregated schools and gasoline would still contain lead.
I am asked to be open minded and listen to both sides. But when one side is speaking babble from infants, and rascist jargon and disdain for the poor, what quality of conversation will we be having? I spent 40 years reading, teaching, working, parenting and I refuse to placate lazy, selfish people.

No point in making an effort to be polite or articulate, this guy is cow flop personified. I'm glad the Times let him speak here. Now many more people will see what a creep he is.

Informed intelligent readers will see this clown for what he is, a moron. He is a moron because he thinks anything he wants to say or write is true because he is the author. Never mind a quick internet search. Oh, and lets not touch the police or fire fighters unions.

"Over the last few weeks, angry voters have greeted Republican congressmen in districts around the country. As someone who has confronted similar crowds before — and lived to tell about it — I have a simple message for those lawmakers: It’s put-up or shut-up time." The voice of Republican wisdom, or wis dumb?

Hope the Wisconsinites who put this clown in office are enjoying their states downward spiral.

How stupid is Walker? Read this column from a Wisconsin paper/blog, Urban Milwaukee.

http://urbanmilwaukee.com/2015/07/01/murphys-law-wisconsins-rotten-retur...

Living in Wisconsin, watching the accelerating decline of our formerly progressive state, and waking up this morning to see a Scott Walker opinion in the NYT is quite surreal. I am used to reading intelligent, usually quite well reasoned opinions. Even those I disagree with are at least well worth the read to hear another perspective.

Walker and his Republicans in control of Wisconsin are quickly following the exact road that has led Kansas to disaster.

Walker's opinions are more appropriate to the Brietbart website, than here at our nation's paper of record.

My radical proposal is that we do away with states or severely limit their autonomy. In a mobile and highly interconnected society why should we be functioning on an 18th century government model that assumed a mostly agrarian, slow moving nation? Keep state boundaries as cultural artifacts so that people born within them can continue to root for whatever college football team resides therein. But we are, as a nation, poorly served by 50 powerful polities where my rights vary depending upon which side of an arbitrary line I live on. It's time for legislative and electoral power to be granted equally to all people regardless of where they live.

I live in a very blue city in a deep red state. Likewise, there are very conservative concentration in California. Why should either of us, liberal or conservative, be at the mercy of these traditional regional entities? Our ideological coalitions are formed by more by the internet than geography. There are a host of issues that would be better resolved by a single, national policy rather than 50 individual ones.
Really an excellent suggestion. The states, so easily gerrymandered, now serve as institutional barriers to the democratic republic. They are an artifact no longer needed and should be pruned.

Scot Walker leaves out the Gov. of Kansas who has followed ALEC policies to the letter, gutted taxes, and in turn gutted public services including education. He was just lambasted by the courts for not funding public education at an acceptable level. And if Walker needs workers who are drug free, he might consider a massive prevention program, early adolescent screening, treatment on demand using evidence based practices, and recovery support. You might also actually work to improve schools, all the schools, and institute post K-12 training for this century's jobs.
When Walker and company's ideology trumps common sense, people get hurt.

"Or take my battle with Washington to test people seeking public assistance for drug use. They should be employed or enrolled in job training, looking for work five times a week and able to pass a drug test. If they fail, we would get them into rehab and into the work force."

I was unemployed for a couple years after the 2008 crash. I have a college education and twenty years of good professional experience that kept me from getting any lower-level jobs I applied for.

So Gov. Walker would drug-test me and force me into "job training".

Perhaps he should stop being so condescending to people who have worked all their lives but find themselves in trouble not of their own making. Perhaps his first concern should be stopping another 2008 debacle with stronger laws for Wall Street. Perhaps the drug testing should be done on Wall Street.

And perhaps he and his cronies need to start looking at what's been happening to employment in this country. I'm sure that the people who are working for less nowadays in the Trump crowds would be surprised to learn that in voting for a strongman, they were voting for—what was it?—"returning power to the States".

First of all, it was in 2011 when he first became governor, that Scott Walker dropped Act 10 on us. It has still never been shown to my satisfaction the undue influence public employee unions were exerting. If that premise were true, it seems Mr. Walker would still be Milwaukee County Executive, not governor. And the Republicans would not have gained control of both houses of the state legislature in the midterms of 2010.
The real issue for Walker and his sort has always been about squelching the only alternative voice out there to millionaire and billionaire manipulators of public policy. It was never about budgets or saving money. (And it's not just about public sector unions - see: "right to work.") Unfortunately, what has been lost in all of this is something more important than political influence, which as I said was evidently nonexistent. What was lost was the ability for workers to advocate for their own self-interest at work and for the continued raising of the quality of work and working conditions. There is nothing radical, sinister, or evil in the notion that those who do the real work in our society have some sort of say in how that work gets done, in what conditions, and to what extent that work shares in the productivity it generates. It's only fair.
There is nothing radical, sinister, or evil in the notion of fairness.

In Wisconsin, since Scott Walker has been governor, our roads no longer get repaired and are in horrible condition, you weave around potholes or pay the price. Our bridges are in disrepair. Our DNR is removing science from its website and shutting it much beloved magazine, which is paid for by subscription. Money for public schools has been slashed and of course, it’s our children who pay that price. Our world-class university is losing rank. In 2016 we were ranked 33 in job creation and last in startups. Our beautiful state, which led the country in fairness and sound environmental policy, has truly suffered under Gov. Scott Walker.

Here in Wisconsin we have lived the Walker version of the "high road". Maybe he was referring to passing Act 10 in the dead of night without input from constituents? Or vilifying our hard working teachers and state employees and creating the most divisive environment our state has ever experienced? Or refusing to meet with his constituents and instructing GOP represtatives to follow suit?

And for what? Our state has plummeted in job creation and University researchers and instructors are leaving in droves. Our state is more divided than I have seen in my lifetime.

Even worse, teachers and state employees have become "the bad guys".
We've lived this Trumpist fear based divisive rhetoric in Wisconsin for years.

Our state suffers while Walker chases his political advancement.

My advice, resistance, diligence, then repeat. Do not give up.

We were blindsided in Wisconsin, that's certainly not the case with the glaringly obvious incompetence of the Trump administration.
